title: Vladimir Shevchenko
text:
Jeg verdsetter ærlighet, ansvar og presisjon i arbeidet mitt. Jeg er interessert i IT og liker å jobbe med dataanalyse og visualisering.
Jeg har erfaring med Python og R, og bruker verktøy som Quarto og SQL. Jeg er også godt kjent med MS Office og LibreOffice/WPS Office. De siste fire årene har jeg brukt Linux som mitt primære system i hverdagen.
Jeg liker IT-relatert arbeid, og det trenger ikke nødvendigvis å være programmering – det kan også inkludere relaterte felt som elektroteknikk, finans eller andre tekniske områder. Jeg er ivrig etter å lære, nysgjerrig og åpen for å tilegne meg new ferdigheter.
På fritiden liker jeg å være utendørs og tilbringe tid med familie og venner. Jeg verdsetter en god balanse mellom arbeid og privatliv, men jeg er fleksibel og villig til å hjelpe til når det trengs.





Ukraina, Melitopol | «Melitopol Melkefabrikk» | Juni 2023 – Desember 2023

Utarbeidelse og oppdatering av selskapets balanser
Varekontroll av ferdige produkter og materialer
Analyse av salgsdata etter butikker
Beregning av produksjonskostnader
Automatisering og optimalisering av arbeidsflyter ved hjelp av Python, R og SQL for å forbedre effektiviteten




Ukraina, Kyiv | «Forward Bank LLC» | November 2020 – Oktober 2022

Utarbeidelse av risikoanalyserapporter
Kundekontroll i henhold til interne krav
Utvikling og optimalisering av skript for automatiserte datakontroller (R/SQL)
Implementering av nye beregninger for risikovurdering
Oracle tabelladministrasjon
Datarensing og forberedelse
Databehandling for analyse




Ukraina, Kyiv | «Band» | 2016 - 2018

Ekstern teknisk støtte for brukere
Installasjon og konfigurasjon av programvare for Windows og Linux
Leie og administrere VPS (VDS) servere
Automatisering av arbeidsflyt







Statens landbruks-teknologiske universitet | 2016 – 2020
Informasjonsteknologi, Heltid









 Telegram |  E-post |  Last ned CV



Fødselsdato: 29.08.1997
Kjønn: Mann
Sivilstatus: Ugift
Nasjonalitet: Ukraina
Sted: Bjørnafjorden, Norge
Jobbsøk: Åpen for muligheter







Kontorpakker: MS, Libre, Only Office
Databaser: Oracle, SQLite, DuckDB
Språk: R, Python
BI-systemer: Apache Superset
Rapportering: RMarkdown, Quarto





Språk: Bash, Python, Go
Containere: Docker/Podman
Virtualisering: Qemu
Versjonskontroll: Git, Forgejo

title: Vladimir Shevchenko
text:
I value honesty, responsibility, and precision in my work. I am interested in IT and enjoy working with data analysis and visualization.
I have experience with Python and R, and use tools like Quarto and SQL. I am also well-versed in MS Office and LibreOffice/WPS Office. For the past four years, I have been using Linux as my primary system in daily life.
I enjoy IT-related work, and it does not necessarily have to be programming-it can also include related fields such as electrical engineering, finance, or other technical areas. I am eager to learn, curious, and open to acquiring new skills.
In my free time, I enjoy being outdoors and spending time with family and friends. I value a good work-life balance, but I am flexible and willing to help when needed.





Ukraina, Melitopol | «Melitopol Milk Factory» | June 2023 – December 2023

Preparation and updating of company balance sheets
Inventory control of finished products and materials
Analysis of sales data by stores
Calculation of production costs
Automation and optimization of workflows using Python, R, and SQL to improve efficiency




Ukraina, Kyiv | «Forward Bank LLC» | November 2020 – October 2022

Preparation of risk analysis reports
Client control according to internal requirements
Development and optimization of scripts for automated data checks (R/SQL)
Implementation of new metrics for risk assessment
Oracle table administration
Data cleaning and preparation
Data processing for analysis

title: Sales Report
text:
Binol stores with an area of up to 15m²
The presented chart shows the month-by-month sales dynamics. The data indicates that sales volumes in such outlets experience significant fluctuations throughout the year.






NoteNote



Data for the store 57/9 Kirova Street is unavailable due to its closure.














Binol stores with an area of 15m² or more












Total by months
The total revenue from the sale of Binol and Olive flowers.






NoteNote



The revenue from Olive was deducted from the total sales of the stores. That is, the Binol figures also include third-party products (warehouse goods).

title: Cheese sales
text:
library(plotrix)
library(dplyr)

df <- tibble(
  NM = c("Cheddar", "Mozzarella", "Brie", "Parmesan", "Gouda"),
  SUM = c(279158, 231399, 606614, 586469, 267434)
) %>% mutate(PROC = round((SUM / summarise(.,sum(SUM)) %>% as.double())*100,1) %>% paste0('%'))
Example of a 3D Pie Chart using the plotrix library
pie3D(df$SUM, mar = rep(1,4),
      col = hcl.colors(length(df$NM), "Heat 2"),
      labels = paste0(df$NM, '\n',round(df$SUM/1000), ' (', df$PROC, ')'),
      main = "Cheese sales",
      height=0.1,
      radius=0.8,
      labelcex = 1,
      explode = 0.1)

title: Web Scraping
text:
This code allows you to parse information about vacancies on hh.ru It scans the home page, finds vacancies, follows links to vacancies and collects the specified data

Import and settings
The main libraries for parsing are: 1. requests- makes a request to the site and receives data 2. bs4(BeautifulSoup) - parses the result of the request requests

import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import polars as pl
import re
import xlsxwriter
import time

1df = pl.DataFrame({
    "URL": pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Utf8),
    "Вакансия": pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Utf8),
    "Зарплата": pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Int64)
    "Keyword": pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Utf8),
    "Tags": pl.Series([], dtype=pl.Utf8)
})

2query = "excel"

start_url = "https://hh.ru/search/vacancy?experience=between1And3" \
    "&order_by=publication_time&ored_clusters=true" \
    f"&schedule=remote&text={query}&search_period=7"

3url = start_url

4  headers = {
      "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 11.0; Win64; x64)" \
        "AppleWebKit/538.33 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/98.0.4472.124 Safari/537.36",
      "Accept-Language": "ru-RU,ru;q=0.9",
      "Accept-Encoding": "gzip, deflate, br",
      "Connection": "keep-alive",
      "Upgrade-Insecure-Requests": "1"
  }

5  keywords = ["BPMN", "Jira"]


1

create an empty table, the found information about vacancies will be added to this table

2

start page of the request, this line takes into account the specified filters on hh, that is, you can go to hh, specify the search criteria, select filters, and then copy the link and paste it into the script

3

this link serves as the main one for the transition, to go to the second page you need to add page=page numberto the link, I use the code url=f'{start_url}&page={p}' which has a page constant start_urld, and concatenation depending on the iteration of the loop

4

these settings are needed when requesting requests.get(), to simulate that the user makes a request for the page, when the site requests data, we provide him with data from this list

5

keywords that the script will search for on the vacancy pages






Checking the received page (job vacancy)
When requesting a page, there are cases where an incomplete page is received, missing some data This function checks for the presence of data, and if it’s incomplete, it re-requests the page

def check_correctly(url):
1     for i in range(9):
2          response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
3          soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')

4          header = soup.find('div', {'class': 'vacancy-title'})
5          if header:
6               visit_and_check(url, soup, response)
               break


1

If the data is incomplete, we repeat the request

2

The request to retrieve data from the website, url - the link to the data being requested, headers - this is the user-agent created earlier

3

Parse the received object (which now contains the “roughly speaking” HTML page), which can be parsed. The advantage is that during testing, no request is made to the website

4

Look for the div class named vacancy-title

5

Check the header variable (why? Read the header description) to confirm if we received the complete page

6

Call the function and pass url - the link, soup - the local HTML, response - for searching words across the entire page






Scanning the job vacancy
This function extracts the necessary data from the page

def visit_and_check(url, soup, response):
1  global df

2  fkeys = []

3  for keyword in keywords:
4      if keyword in response.text:
5        fkeys.append(keyword)
  # Finding tags (skills) at the bottom of the page
6  skill_elements = soup.find_all('li', {'data-qa': 'skills-element'})
  skills = [li.find('div', class_=re.compile(r'magritte-tag__label')).text for li in skill_elements]

7  header = soup.find('div', {'class': 'vacancy-title'})
8  title = header.find('h1').text

9  salary_str = header.find('span', {'data-qa': 'vacancy-salary-compensation-type-net'})
  if salary_str:
    # Find the first number in a string using a regular expression
      match = re.search(r'\d+', salary_str.text.replace('\xa0', ''))
      if match:
        salary = int(match.group())
      else:
        salary = None
  else:
    salary = None

10  df = df.vstack(pl.DataFrame({
    "URL": [url],
    "Вакансия" : [title],
    "Зарплата" : [salary],
    "Keyword": [', '.join(fkeys)],
    "Tags": [', '.join(skills)]}))


1

This line is needed because of namespaces. The function is called for each job vacancy, and the result of the extracted data needs to be saved in a table. (After the function exits, all objects created inside it are deleted). Therefore, the table is created outside the function, globally, and this line is necessary to access the global table

2

This list will contain the words found on the page (the list of words is specified in the keywords variable)

3

The search for the keys specified in keywords happens here, with each keyword being processed one at a time

4

The search for the key (word) is performed on the response.text object, which is the text returned by the website request

5

If a keyword is found on the page, it is added to the empty list fkeys (which was created earlier)

6

We search for the necessary data in the local HTML, which we parsed. In this case, we are looking for tags in the bottom part of the page

7

Extract the header

8

Get the job title

9

Get the salary rate (specified salary) Note: Some vacancies do not specify a salary, and there are cases where a salary range from…to is provided. These cases are handled below:

10

Save the extracted data into the table






Page navigation and link search
This loop scans the main pages (where job vacancies are located), depending on the iteration, it navigates through pages 2, 3, 4… on the website

1for p in range(9):
    if p > 0:
2        url = f'{start_url}&page={p}'
        print(f"--- Page {p} --- --- ---")

    # Searching for all links inside h2 tags
3    for i in range(9):
4        time.sleep(3)
        print(f"--- --- --- Iteration {i}")
5        response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
6        soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
7        if soup.find_all('h2'):
            for h2 in soup.find_all('h2'):
                for a in h2.find_all('a', href=True):
                    absolute_url = requests.compat.urljoin(url, a['href'])
8                    check_correctly(absolute_url)
9            break


1

Specify the number of main pages (where job vacancies are located) to scan

2

If this is not the first iteration of the loop, add “page” and the page number (the current iteration number) to the URL

3

Sometimes hh.ru returns an incomplete page, so in this loop, we check the validity of the received page. If it’s incomplete, we repeat the request until a complete page is obtained or until the number in the range() function is reached

4

Before each new request, wait a little to avoid DDOSing the website. The goal is to gather data, simulating a simple navigation

5

The request to retrieve data from the website, url - the link to the data being requested, headers - this is the user-agent that was created earlier

6

Parse the received object (which now contains the “roughly speaking” HTML page), which can be parsed. The advantage is that during testing, no request is made to the website

7

Check the received page. If it’s incomplete, make another request (proceed to the next iteration)

8

Pass the job vacancy link to the checking variable

9

At this stage, when we reach if soup.find_all('h2'), it means we have obtained the full link to the page, so no new request is needed for the same link






Save
Save the result to an xlsx file
1wb = xlsxwriter.Workbook('Output.xlsx')
2ws = wb.add_worksheet('DF')

3df.write_excel(
    workbook=wb,
    worksheet='DF',
    position="A1",
    table_style="Table Style Medium 3",
    dtype_formats={pl.Date: "mm/dd/yyyy"},
    column_totals={"score": "average"},
    float_precision=1,
    autofit=True,
)


4ws.set_column('A:A', 10)
ws.set_column('B:B', 40)
ws.set_column('C:C', 10)
ws.set_column('D:D', 20)
ws.set_column('E:E', 90)

5wb.close()

1

Create a workbook object

2

Create a sheet

3

Insert the table into the xlsx sheet and specify the column formats

4

Set the width of the columns

5

Close the xlsx file




Result





 Back to top

title: Beautiful export to Excel (xlsx)
text:
NoteNote



This article briefly describes the functions of the openxlsx package. Below is an example of the interaction of functions and the final result of exporting a table from R → xlsx



Libraryes and styles
library(openxlsx)

## --- Colors
gray   <- createStyle(fgFill = '#d9d9d9')
green  <- createStyle(fgFill = '#c6e0b4')
red    <- createStyle(fgFill = '#f9a1a1')
blue   <- createStyle(fgFill = '#bdd7ee')
yellow <- createStyle(fgFill = '#ffe699')
ros    <- createStyle(fgFill = '#fce4d6')
border <- createStyle(fgFill = '#333333')

## --- Styles
st_bord <- createStyle(numFmt = "#,##0",
                       border = 'TopBottomLeftRight',borderColour = '#cccccc')
st_head <- createStyle(textDecoration = "bold", halign = "center",
                       border = 'TopBottomLeftRight',borderColour = border)
st_bot  <- createStyle(textDecoration = 'bold',border = "top",
                       borderColour = border,borderStyle = "medium")
st_name <- createStyle(halign = "center", textDecoration = 'bold',
                       fontSize = 16, border = 'TopBottomLeftRight',
                       borderColour = border, borderStyle = 'medium')
st_bold <- createStyle(textDecoration = 'bold',border = "left",
                       borderColour = border,borderStyle = "medium")


Workbook and Options
We create a workbook (an object in RAM) and a sheet in this workbook named Sales, to which we apply several options: - orientation = ‘portrait’ - specifies the paper orientation (an option for printing on paper) - pageSetup – for page margin (helps fit more information on the page when printing on paper)
## Create a book
wb <- createWorkbook()

## Adding a Sheet to the xlsx Workbook
addWorksheet(wb, sheetName = "Sales", orientation = 'portrait', gridLines = FALSE)

## Setting Margins
pageSetup(wb, "Sales", left = 0.25, top = 0.25, right = 0.25,bottom = 0.25)


Writing and Customization
## Writing Data to the xlsx Sheet
writeData(wb, 'Sales', "Sales")

## Merging Cells
1mergeCells(wb, sheet = "Sales", cols = 1:length(fin_sales), rows = 1)

2addStyle(wb, 'Sales', st_name, 1, 1:length(fin_sales), stack = TRUE)

writeData(wb, 'Sales', fin_sales, startRow = 3)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', st_head, 3, 1:length(fin_sales),
         gridExpand = TRUE, stack = TRUE)

1

merges cells (the range of merged cells is determined automatically)  cols = 1:length(fin_sales)

2

applies the “st_name” style to the specified range


## Set Column Widths
1setColWidths(wb, "Sales", cols = 1, widths = 25)

addStyle(wb, 'Sales', st_bord, 4:(nrow(fin_sales)+3),
         1:length(fin_sales), stack = TRUE, gridExpand = TRUE)

## Apply the st_bot Style to Cells in the Column with Data
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', st_bot, (which(!is.na(temp_sales$PROC))+3),
         1:length(temp_sales), stack = TRUE, gridExpand = TRUE)

addStyle(wb, 'Sales', st_bot, nrow(fin_sales)+3, 1:length(fin_sales), stack = TRUE)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', createStyle(halign = "center"),
         3:(nrow(fin_sales)+3), length(fin_sales), stack = TRUE, gridExpand = TRUE)
setColWidths(wb, "Sales", cols = length(fin_sales), widths = 18)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', gray, 3, 1, stack = TRUE)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', ros, 3, c(2,3), stack = TRUE, gridExpand = TRUE)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', green, 3, 4, stack = TRUE)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', blue, 3, 5, stack = TRUE)
addStyle(wb, 'Sales', yellow, 3, 6, stack = TRUE)

1

setColWidths - sets the width of the column




Result



Conclusion
This method of saving to xlsx is, on one hand, “verbose,” but on the other hand, it is very flexible in customization, allowing you to write/apply styles down to the individual cell.
If a similar report is generated regularly, where only the data is updated, this approach makes sense. In the long term, it will pay off in subsequent iterations of report generation.




 Back to top

title: OCR Reader
text:
Get img from clipboard
Function for get screenshot from clipboard
def get_image_from_clipboard():
1    result = subprocess.run(['xclip', '-selection', 'clipboard', '-t', 'image/png', '-o'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)

2    if result.returncode != 0:
        raise Exception("Can't get screenshot")

    return io.BytesIO(result.stdout)

1

Get screenshot from clipboard

2

Exception

title: OCR Reader
text:
Copy result into clipboard
The func for copy OCR result in clipboard
def copy_text_to_clipboard(text):
    subprocess.run(['xclip', '-selection', 'clipboard'], input=text.encode(), check=True)

title: Binol vs Olive
text:
Binol and Olive is concurire market for buys a flowers

Library

from sqlalchemy import create_engine
import duckdb as db
import polars as pl

from matplotlib.ticker import FuncFormatter
import matplotlib.dates as mdates
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from locale import setlocale, LC_TIME



Get data asdasdasd

con = db.connect("~/Documents/kbase/local.db")

df = con.execute("""
  select * from portfolio.salles_binol_olivia
  where Shops in ('Washington 24', 'Pine 3', 'Cedar 19a', 'Park Avenue 12', 'King Street 25', 'Victoria 38/4')
""").pl().with_columns(
    pl.col('DT').str.to_date(format='%Y-%m-%d')
  )



Agregate table

sns.set_theme()

df_melted = df.melt(id_vars=["DT", "Shops"], value_vars=["Binol", "Olive"],
                    variable_name="Product", value_name="Value")

g = sns.FacetGrid(df_melted,
                  col='Shops',
                  hue='Product',        # coloring with a new color
                  col_wrap=3,           # number of plots displayed in one row
                  sharey=False,         # y-axis shared across all plots
                  sharex=False,         # x-axis shared across all plots
                  height=4)             # height

g = g.map(sns.lineplot, 'DT', 'Value', marker='o', markersize=4)

# Apply formatting function to the Y-axis of each subplot
for ax in g.axes.flat:
    # Increase the maximum Y-axis value by 10%
    ylim = ax.get_ylim()
    ax.set_ylim((ylim[0], ylim[1] * 1.1))

    # Draw trend lines for each line in ax.lines
    for line in ax.lines:
        sns.regplot(
            x=line.get_xdata(), y=line.get_ydata(), ax=ax,
            scatter=False,         # No markers (only trend line)
            color='gray',          # Set line color to gray
            ci=None,               # No confidence interval shading
            line_kws={'linestyle': '--'}  # Dashed line
        )
    # Format X-axis labels
    ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mdates.DateFormatter('%b'))

# Text annotation function
def f(x, y, **kwargs):
    ax = plt.gca()  # Get current axis
    for i in range(len(x)):
        ax.annotate(f"{y.values[i]:.1f}", xy=(x.values[i], y.values[i]), fontsize=8,
                    xytext=(0, 10), textcoords="offset points",
                    color="black",  # Set color same as line color
                    bbox=dict(boxstyle="round", ec="none", fc="gray", alpha=0.3, pad=0.3),
                    va="center", ha="center")

g.map(f, 'DT', 'Value')

g.fig.subplots_adjust(top=.9)         # space for the suptitle from the plot
g.fig.suptitle('Salles')              # title of the plot

g.add_legend(title="Product")
sns.move_legend(
    g, "center", bbox_to_anchor=(.5, 1), ncol=5, title=None, frameon=False,
)

# specify X/Y axis labels
g.set_axis_labels("Date", "Amount")

# set the title of each subplot based on the data table
g.set_titles("{col_name}")

plt.show()












 Back to top

title: Владимир Шевченко
text:
Я ценю честность, ответственность и точность в своей работе. Меня интересуют информационные технологии, и мне нравится работать с анализом и визуализацией данных.
У меня есть опыт работы с Python и R, и я использую такие инструменты, как Quarto и SQL. Я также хорошо владею MS Office и LibreOffice/WPS Office. Последние четыре года я использую Linux в качестве основной системы в повседневной жизни.
Мне нравится работа, связанная с ИТ, и это не обязательно должно быть программирование — это могут быть и смежные области, такие как электротехника, финансы или другие технические сферы. Я стремлюсь к обучению, любопытен и открыт для приобретения новых навыков.
В свободное время я люблю бывать на свежем воздухе и проводить время с семьей и друзьями. Я ценю хороший баланс между работой и личной жизнью, но я гибок и готов помочь, когда это необходимо.

title: Володимир Шевченко
text:
Я ціную чесність, відповідальність та точність у своїй роботі. Мене цікавлять інформаційні технології, і мені подобається працювати з аналізом та візуалізацією даних.
Я маю досвід роботи з Python та R, і використовую такі інструменти, як Quarto та SQL. Я також добре володію MS Office та LibreOffice/WPS Office. Протягом останніх чотирьох років я використовую Linux як основну систему в повсяkdenному житті.
Мені подобається робота, пов’язана з ІТ, і це не обов’язково має бути програмування — це можуть бути і суміжні галузі, такі як електротехніка, фінанси або інші технічні сфери. Я прагну до навчання, допитливий і відкритий для здобуття нових навичок.
У вільний час я люблю бувати на свіжому повітрі та проводити час із сім’єю та друзями. Я ціную хороший баланс між роботою та особистим життям, але я гнучкий і готовий допомогти, коли це необхідно.





Україна, Мелітополь | «Мелітопольський молочний завод» | Червень 2023 – Грудень 2023

Підготовка та оновлення балансів компанії
Контроль запасів готової продукції та матеріалів
Аналіз даних про продажі по магазинах
Розрахунок собівартості продукції
Автоматизація та оптимізація робочих процесів з використанням Python, R та SQL для підвищення ефективності




Україна, Київ | «Forward Bank LLC» | Листопад 2020 – Жовтень 2022

Підготовка звітів з аналізу ризиків
Контроль клієнтів відповідно до внутрішніх вимог
Розробка та оптимізація скриптів для автоматизованої перевірки даних (R/SQL)
Впровадження нових метрик для оцінки ризиків
